stream_context.summary: Kaze programmed the behavior for a new 'Thimble Guy' enemy, including a lengthy debugging session for a shine effect. He then conducted a detailed review of a major graphical and layout overhaul of Course 1 submitted by artist Biobak, testing it on hardware. Finally, he began creating another new enemy, 'Bert the Bashful,' iterating on its design and programming its basic jumping behavior. Throughout the stream, he also discussed his YouTube strategy, personal philosophies, and the game's overall structure.

development_findings.summary: The design for the Thimble Guy enemy evolved from an unbeatable pursuer to an enemy that functions like the Bullies from the original game. They are defeated by being knocked off platforms, and they also knock Mario back, creating a dynamic interaction.
development_findings.quote: I think it needs to knock mario back too... I was thinking they should work more like bully fights where you kick them off the thing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent a significant amount of time debugging a graphical effect, eventually tracing it to a shadowed variable that the compiler didn't warn him about. He later discovered that pasting the code into ChatGPT would have identified the bug immediately.
development_findings.quote: And this is why you don't trust your fucking compiler. You look at the assembly and then you find it out. Fuck you, GCC... Oh no, ChetGPD caught that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze reviewed a major visual rework of Course 1 by Biobak, praising the new windmill, improved textures, better background, and overall higher quality. He tested it on N64 hardware and confirmed the performance was maintained despite the visual upgrade.
development_findings.quote: The bunny on here is better. I like that. Oh, we have proper walls here. Okay. The grass looks a lot more detailed... Oh, that's a sick windmill.

development_findings.summary: The design for the 'Bert the Bashful' enemy was iterated on during the stream. Kaze felt the initial version looked 'cheap' and brainstormed with chat to make it look more like a handcrafted, painted egg with a pom-pom nose to better fit the level's aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I like him, but he doesn't look very handcrafted... I like him to look like a painted egg. But the sharp cutout here is kind of ruining that.

development_findings.summary: The game is planned to have approximately 180 stars in total, split between 135 main stars and 45 'Yoshi Stars,' which are special challenges with unique restrictions, such as limiting A-presses.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna have, I think, around 135 main stars. And then we're gonna have 45 Yoshi stars. These Yoshi stars are missions that Yoshi's give you that have like special restrictions.

development_findings.summary: The project is nearing the completion of its main courses, with the team currently working on the 14th out of 15 planned main levels.
development_findings.quote: It is going to be like 30 levels in total, but 15 main courses and we're on the 14th.

development_findings.summary: The 'Bert the Bashful' enemy is designed to not deal damage but instead bounce Mario back, making it a threat primarily through environmental hazards like bottomless pits, similar to its behavior in Yoshi's Island.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to create more mainstream-friendly YouTube content, like 'Mario 64 facts' videos, to grow his channel, contrasting his approach with the more 'scientific' style of creators like Pannenkoek.
context_findings.quote: I think that's the kind of slop that YouTube viewers love and I think we can get famous that way.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a controversial view he encountered, linking a developer's use of premade engines to being 'woke' and implying that building a custom engine is a sign of superior, 'not woke' programming skill.
context_findings.quote: The thing about woke people is they can't program, which is why they have to use premade engines like Unreal Engine or Unity or Godot, right? So if you use your own engine, it's not woke anymore. I learned this yesterday on Twitter.

context_findings.summary: After an interview with a company that gathers data for AI, Kaze formed a strong negative opinion on the utility of Large Language Models (LLMs), considering them to be overhyped.
context_findings.quote: I have just gotten 100% sure that all large language models are just garbage. It's not going anywhere. It's not gonna be ever useful. Other than a better Google.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed intense frustration with German bureaucracy, stating it has had a lasting negative impact on his quality of life even after moving to Canada in 2021.
context_findings.quote: I'm so glad I don't live in germany anymore. Oh god, all the bureaucracy bullshit in germany has ruined my quality of life even now that I no longer live in germany.

context_findings.summary: Acknowledging the legal risks of the project, Kaze plans to seek legal advice before the final release, likely influenced by past experiences with Nintendo taking down his content.
context_findings.quote: I will probably talk to a lawyer Before I release R.T.Y.I.

context_findings.summary: Kaze stated he feels no pressure to play games upon their release, preferring to experience them on his own terms rather than participating in the immediate cultural hype.
context_findings.quote: I don't need to be part of the cultural experience. I just wanna enjoy the game for what it is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze had a 'revelation' about the game's overworld, envisioning it as a complete, explorable 360-degree version of Yoshi's Island to enhance the feeling of adventure and discovery.
context_findings.quote: I was thinking for the overworld. It is super important that the overworld is the entirety of Yoshi's Island. It is important that you get like a 360° round view... so it feels like you can actually explore the entire island.

biobak.summary: Biobak delivered a major graphical and performance overhaul for Course 1, significantly improving its visuals while reducing polygon and material counts, which Kaze praised extensively.
biobak.quote: Quick facts, 220 fewer tries, 7 fewer materials, that is insane.

biobak.summary: A key part of the workflow is Kaze fixing texture formats from Biobak's work, as Biobak's tools or setup prevent him from exporting and testing the assets in-game himself.
biobak.quote: I have to fix formats from Biobak's file. Because he doesn't always know what the correct formats are... he can't export this thing. So he can't check it.

badub.summary: Badub composed a song for the craft-themed level. While Kaze acknowledged its quality and influences, he felt it didn't match the level's adventurous tone and lacked a strong, hummable melody.
badub.quote: It doesn't fit the vibe. Feels more like a beach at sunset. Not like a complete adventure, you know. And I'm also kinda missing the melody that you can hum along to.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned he recently started playing Minecraft for the first time with Zeina.

key_stories.title: The Thimble Guy's Shine
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to implement a moving shine effect on an enemy's head. After a lengthy debugging session that involved checking multiple emulators and the compiled assembly, he discovered the problem was a classic C programming error—a shadowed variable—that his compiler didn't warn him about.
key_stories.challenge: A dynamic shine effect on the Thimble Guy's metallic head was not rendering correctly, despite the code appearing correct.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent a significant amount of time debugging the issue. He tried different emulators, checked hardware behavior, suspected a compiler bug, and eventually dove into the assembly code to find the root cause.
key_stories.outcome: The issue was a shadowed variable (`gfx`) inside a conditional block, which Kaze found by inspecting the compiled assembly. He later humorously noted that ChatGPT identified the bug instantly, and with the fix, the effect worked as intended.
key_stories.key_quote: And this is why you don't trust your fucking compiler. You look at the assembly and then you find it out. Fuck you, GCC.

key_stories.title: The Level's Soundtrack
key_stories.summary: Kaze reviewed a new music track from composer Badub. After soliciting feedback from his audience, Kaze shared his own critique that the song's vibe was too relaxed and didn't fit the adventurous feel of the level, creating a point of creative friction that needs to be resolved.
key_stories.challenge: The music track created by the composer, Badub, for the craft-themed level did not align with Kaze's vision for the level's atmosphere.
key_stories.process: Kaze played the new song on stream, deliberately asking for the audience's opinion before sharing his own to get an unbiased reaction. He then articulated his specific feedback, noting it sounded more like 'Doki Doki Literature Club' and lacked a hummable melody fitting an adventure.
key_stories.outcome: The choice of music remains unresolved. While the stream chat reacted positively, Kaze's critique suggests that the track will need to be revised or replaced to better fit the level's intended feel.
key_stories.key_quote: It doesn't fit the vibe. Feels more like a beach at sunset. Not like a complete adventure, you know.

key_stories.title: The Course 1 Overhaul
key_stories.summary: Artist Biobak delivered a massive, unsolicited overhaul of Course 1. Kaze was initially skeptical but became incredibly excited upon seeing the changes. He verified that the visually stunning new version ran at the same framerate on real hardware, marking a major collaborative win for the team.
key_stories.challenge: Course 1, an early level, needed a significant visual and technical upgrade to match the project's evolving quality standards without sacrificing performance.
key_stories.process: Biobak, the artist, independently performed a complete overhaul of the level's models, textures, and layout, providing a detailed changelog. Kaze reviewed the changes in Blender, loaded the level in-game, and performed tests on an N64 to verify performance.
key_stories.outcome: The reworked level was a resounding success. Kaze confirmed on N64 hardware that the performance was nearly identical to the old version, despite the massive visual improvements. This successful collaboration sets a new quality bar for the game's levels.
key_stories.key_quote: Holy shit! That would be crazy. I will definitely look at it in-game then.
